some of the terms I just wanted to recapture with you just so you understand how we're

So as a first example here, when we talk about foundational models, that's kind of the base
that Kevin Scott would have talked about in the keynote this morning of which large language models you are using
or small language models you are using inside of your copilot.
And the orchestrator is really the brains.
That's the thing that takes all the data at the top of the stack and brings it to the
large language model to then understand what it does with it and how it responds to the
user, and then the orchestrator throws that back up to the user in our user experience. And the key thing is by default the orchestrator has access to this knowledge
and that knowledge is the M365 data that's inside of that Microsoft Graph.
But what we're seeing with AI platforms is this notion of triggers. And triggers is that
concept of being able to proactively reach out to your user through that copilot to do certain things based on events happening in other systems.
You'd see this traditionally in things like how we use webhooks or change notifications in the graph.
But now we're bringing that triggers concept in the concept of how we use Microsoft 365 copilot and other AI platforms.
And then alongside knowledge as a way to get access to information, we have
this notion of actions. And actions is all about calling out to external systems outside
of the knowledge that the orchestrator has access to to get information from other systems.
And these are federated API calls, whether I'm using the semantic kernel, whether I'm
using Copart for Microsoft 365 or any other BYO AI platform stack you're bringing.
And what we've seen very, very early on with AI is that you like to tailor what that large language model can do.
And so some of the things we've announced today essentially allow you to bring your
own instructions to tailor how a large language model and how the Copilot user experience
works to customize it for the user scenarios you have.
And the demos will show, will bring this into account.
Now the reason I'm explaining this stack is for this next build, which is essentially
that with those choices, there are a few ways, a few paths you can take.
Now naturally when we talk about M365 and we talk about copilot for Microsoft 365, we
have the identity of the user that's logged into Teams or into the Microsoft 365 app or the Copilot.Microsoft.com web application. We're using our own foundational
model in that instance and we have our own orchestrator which you've heard Kevin Stott
talk about from a Sydney perspective. And the knowledge is Microsoft Graph knowledge,
but you can bring your own data into it. And we provide this copilot across all the different Microsoft 365 hubs.
So our first choice that you can pick from is Graph Connectors.
And effectively what Graph Connectors do is bring additional semantic grounding directly
into the Microsoft Graph that the orchestrator has access to.
And the important part with this is that you can put all of that knowledge directly in
there for the orchestrator to query.
And that brings some scenarios that are very, very different from some of the other choices
that we offer on the table.
As an example, when we talk about plug-ins, which is that second choice, again, both of

or a bot command. And so they're not part of the knowledge stack within the AI platform.
They're a little bit higher up. And that provides different alternatives and different pros
and cons that we'll talk about as part of this session.
What we announced new today is what we call declarative coilots. And a declarative copilot allows you to provide those custom work instructions
to really tailor how your large language model works. And the nice thing about a declarative
copilot is you can bring both plug-ins and graph connectors and bundle those in a declarative
copilot alongside those custom workflow instructions.
Now, all of these choices are on top of our stack.
They're on our AI platform.

but in a decision process as a maker or developer right now on what you should be doing this
week. So let's start with Graph Connectors. Graph Connectors, as I say, have been around for
about four years in the platform. And obviously with Copilot, we realized we had a really
good shoe-in ramp to take the existing Graph Connectors we have, the power of Microsoft
Search, and take advantage of those as knowledge with the inside of Copilot for Microsoft 365.
Now you've just seen Rajesh on stage announce Copilot connectors as an overarching term.
Now one piece of clarity I want to bring to the table here is that the Microsoft Graph
connectors are the only connectors that bring the information directly into the knowledge
part of the stack.
All of the Copilot Studio connectors that you can see on the right-hand side of this
slide are actually plug-ins. They're wrapped plug-ins from existing technology
we have in the Power Platform stack, whether they're Power Platform connectors, flows,
Dataverse connectors or Microsoft Fabric connectors. And so there's a little difference between
when you're picking those copilot studio connectors versus this Graph connector which gets straight
into that knowledge of the stack. Now, one of the main benefits that people
pick Graph connectors as their choice is that effectively when you push that data into the
Microsoft Graph, it's in the index of the Microsoft Graph, whenever the orchestrator
uses a prompt like can you give me guidance on operational efficiency, the orchestrator
is never having
to call anything outside the Microsoft boundary because a graph connector is pushing that
content into Microsoft Graph. Your system is pushing information into the Microsoft
Graph and there's never any calls that come outside.
Now where do graph connectors make the most sense? Like most search indexes, unstructured data is really where it sings.
Anything you can take a bunch of information and flatten it into a JSON file or plain text
file and throw that through the Microsoft Graph to get it in our index is really where
it's going to make most sense.
And large language models do a really good job of taking that flattened content and using
it in summarization.
You'll see that in some of the partner demos we'll show today.
Now the beauty of this, in my opinion, is that you don't have to plan much about what
prompts you think your users are going to go do.
Because if you're indexing the entire page, much like a Copilot index is a public website,
you can ask it questions in all different ways because
it's indexing that into a vector database.
And so I can get quite random prompts that I can ask.
And as long as the answer is in the page, most likely the orchestrator and the copilot
is going to work together to make sure that it can find that answer and respond to that
user.
So the notion of unpredictable prompts on large sets of information that's unstructured
is really, really valuable when it comes to graph connectors.
A thing to call out is obviously the fact that it's punching things into the index in
the Microsoft graph means that from a scalability perspective and us defending our API and our
service quality, we can't really have you indexing systems that are very high throughput,
very high transactions.
And so we look for systems in this place that are more low activity updated items.
And so good candidates for that for the Graph Connectors are things like document repositories.
They could be other SaaS providers that you use within your organization or you could
be the vendor that's running those document repositories.
It could be a knowledge base that's running in the cloud like a wiki.
You could be on a public website or an internal website. It could be also content management
systems that you're running for your intranet that might not be SharePoint. You've chosen
to use another product in the ecosystem. All of these things are really good candidates
for being put through as an index for Graph Connectors.
Now this first demo is from a partner called Tiger Hall. And Tiger

here is the user is asked about how he can be more strategic. And that video has actually

But as another example here with what is operational scalability, you'll notice that it's giving

So if we look at plugins, the difference here, if you notice on the screen, is that API plugins
leave the Microsoft 365 boundary because it's calling an API that isn't hosted inside of Microsoft 365.
So that's a choice you have to make by using plugins in this platform.
Now, plugins are really good for real-time data, and especially so for highly relational data.
We mentioned with Graph Connectors, you have to flatten that data to put it in the index.
relational data. We mentioned with Graph Connectors you have to flatten that data to put it in the index. With high relational data, the API, you can build the shapes of your API,
what parameters you need to be able to get at that highly relational data. With Graph
Connectors we do have some limits on how much items you can index inside of Microsoft Graph.
And so if you're dealing with systems that are larger than those limits, then plug-ins
are going to be the best place for you. Plug-ins really rely on you understanding the precision of the
prompts your user is going to ask. Show me the latest issues I'm assigned to. Show me
the projects that I'm assigned to. What are the latest orders that have been reached into
the system? And the nice thing about plug-ins is as well as being able to summarize the data that you
can reach out to through those APIs, you can also do actions on it.
And you saw in Jeff's keynote this ability to go and update the system and confirming
with Copilot you want to do that update.
And obviously if you've already got an API in your system, all you have to do is wrap
that in an open API document, provide a plug-in manifest, and you're off To the races deploying that in your environment.
It's a good way to get started if you have an api with a good
Set of crud capabilities on it. Create, read, update, delete.
Good candidates for plug-ins, as you would expect, all the
Large enterprise systems that have transactional data or are
Dealing with customers and the frequency of the items being
Updated is very, very high. If you have these within your experience or you're a vendor that owns a system like this,
plugins is going to be a good fit for you.
Now there are two ways you can build plugins as has been mentioned before.
